        ``}``
        return input;
``}``

'''java
public void convertCsvToJson(Path csvFilePath, Path jsonFilePath) throws IOException, CsvException ``{``
    try (FileReader fileReader = new FileReader(csvFilePath.toString());
         CSVReader csvReader = new CSVReader(fileReader)) ``{``
        
        List&lt;String[]> rows = csvReader.readAll();

        if (rows.isEmpty()) ``{``
            throw new CsvException("No data");
        ``}``

        List&lt;String[]> personRows = new ArrayList&lt;>();
        List&lt;String[]> timedEventRows = new ArrayList&lt;>();

        boolean isTimedEventSection = false;

        for (String[] row : rows) ``{``
            if (row.length > 0 && row[0].equalsIgnoreCase("timedEvents")) ``{``
                isTimedEventSection = true;
            ``}`` else ``{``
                if (isTimedEventSection) ``{``
                    timedEventRows.add(row);
                ``}`` else ``{``
                    personRows.add(row);
                ``}``
            ``}``

        wrappedData.put("persons", personsData);
        wrappedData.put("timedEvents", timedEventsData);

Seems like the `parseCcaInformation` and `parseCcaInformations` need logic revision. For example, return type Set&lt;CcaInformation> of `parseCcaInformation` seems not accurate. 

For example, parseCcaInformation creates a new CCA instead of referring to one in CcaList. This causes the CcaTotalAttendance not consistent to the actual CCA object in the list.

Considering that this method was set during MVP, unstable iteration, we need to revise this in the later iteration.

I also think it is good to have implement add Cca and delete Cca Commands to mitigate this issue. Since parser object should not have the dependency to the Model (i.e. CcaList), and considering the EditStudentDescriptor (because there is no way we can get CCA object from CCA list in Model in EditStudentDescriptor), I think this is going to be a lot better architecture design.
</panel>

> just to check, if I close the application with light mode, the application will remember the last mode that I used right? (correct me if I am wrong) so is this the best way to do it?

No. That will be done in #170, I think. @GauhVish can help to confirm.

Current implementation is that the app will start with dark theme by default. When the user switches to light mode, it will stay so while the app is open. When it is closed and reopened, the app will go back to dark mode.

The changes I introduced does not change this behaviour; it only ensures the help window will switch to a light theme once when light mode is selected (currently help window remains in dark mode regardless of the color mode chosen).

Hope that clarified your doubts!

```
MSS:
  1. User chooses to transfer money.
  2. OBS requests for details of the transfer.
  3. User enters the requested details.
  4. OBS requests for confirmation.
  5. User confirms.
  6. OBS transfers the money and displays the new account balance.
  Use case ends.
Extensions:
  3a. OBS detects an error in the entered data.
      3a1. OBS requests for the correct data.
      3a2. User enters new data.
      Steps 3a1-3a2 are repeated until the data entered are correct.
      Use case resumes from step 4.
```

Essentially the `fromIndex` is being recursively shortened in the `findPrefixPosistions` method earlier.
So this final else block is to check that the very prefix if applicable is terminating.

If that is not included, because `endsWith` does not take in parameter `fromIndex`, it will recursively flag the last `prefix` as valid, and will result in a recursion loop,
</panel>

Checked coding standard [here](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/intermediate.html).

This should be ok: you either have @params for all or none. 
In particular, the coding standard doesn't seem to advocate what was given originally (i.e. params as in-text to the description). Not very certain why is was used.

@return can be omitted if the method does not return anything or the return value is obvious from the rest of the comment.
@params can be omitted if all parameters of a method have self-explanatory names, or they are already explained in the main part of the comment i.e., if none of the @params add any value. This means the comment will have @param for all its parameters, or none.
</panel>

to be honest idk how to use the message constraints here. Because the Attendance object is created internally (not by user input), and it's just checking whether the given attendance (0,1,2) and week (1-13) are valid. <panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103-F15-4/tp/pull/148#discussion_r2015666088" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**88 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** %%(commented on own PR)%%
</div>

Hmm, I get what you mean. I'm just thinking that it's better to restrict the attendance string to be either empty, or of length 13. Because if we accept a string shorter than 13, we are making the assumption that the digits start from week 1. (length 5 --> weeks 1-5). Similarly, we could then use the same idea to accept a string longer than 13, and add code to truncate anything beyond the 13th character. So from the perspective of isValidAttendanceString, I think it makes sense to only view strings of length 13 as valid. (Also note that this method is technically used "internally", meaning that the user doesn't actually pass in an attendance string in add, edit or att. It's more of a safeguard to ensure the devs don't misuse the AttendanceList.generateAttendanceList method by passing in strings that don't make sense. Hence I feel it's ok to be a bit stricter for internal use, as it doesn't translate to "more convenience" for the user lol.)
</panel>

    public HelpCommand parse(String args) throws ParseException ``{``

        case AddCommand.COMMAND_WORD -&gt; new HelpCommand(AddCommand.COMMAND_WORD, AddCommand.MESSAGE_USAGE,
                "Adds a new contact to the database with optional details.");
        case DeleteCommand.COMMAND_WORD -&gt; new HelpCommand(DeleteCommand.COMMAND_WORD, DeleteCommand.MESSAGE_USAGE,
                "Deletes a existing contact from the database with optional details.");
        case ListCommand.COMMAND_WORD -&gt; new HelpCommand(ListCommand.COMMAND_WORD, ListCommand.COMMAND_WORD,
                "Lists out the contact in the database with optional category.");
        default ->
                throw new ParseException(String.format(MESSAGE_INVALID_COMMAND_FORMAT, HelpCommand.MESSAGE_USAGE));
        ``}``;
    ``}``

</panel>

**25 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on others PR)
</div>

I just took a look at `RemoveTagCommand` in #106, and saw it has repeated codes with `AddTagsCommand` (i.e. `createUpdatedPerson`).

When I reviewed the `AddTagsCommand` previously, I hadn't considered possible implications with the parser (sorry). Following up from the above comment, I am wondering if we could make use of `EditCommand.EditPersonDescriptor` for these new commands.

What I am thinking of is to:

1. Extract `EditPersonDescriptor` into another file (e.g. `CommandUtils`)
2. Shift `EditCommand::createEditPerson` into `EditPersonDescriptor`
3. `[Edit|AddTags|RemoveTag]Command` and its respective parsers to use this

Pros:

- Single point of modification
    * Consider adding a new field for `Person` (e.g. `comments`)
    * We would need to update (at least) 3 constructor methods
- Reduce inconsistency for the app
- Ease of understanding since all uses the same system/logic

Cons:

- May require more time (and effort) to coordinate changes and implement now
- Requires refactoring of existing implementations (i.e. low-medium effort)

A couple of key concepts

2. Each folder has
- An interface which defines to save, read, and to where (XStorage)
- Actual implementation (JsonXStorage) of the operations, which uses...
- A json representation of the object (JsonX)
- A json representation of the collection of object (JsonXManager)
3. Updates to sampleutil class to include sample event and todo lists
4. Updates to execution of application to load sample or present databases, and to save them to the specified default paths.

Resolution behavior with representative example:
Suppose contact 1 has tag `a` already

* `contact tag 1 --tag a a a` -&gt; duplicate tags found
* `contact tag 1 --tag a` -&gt; tag already exists
* `contact edit 1 --tag a a` -&gt; duplicate tags found
* `contact edit 1 --tag a` -&gt; ok, because replacement
* `contact tag 1 --tag a a` -&gt; duplicate tags found
* `contact tag 1 --tag a` -&gt; tag already exists
* `contact untag 1 --tag a a` -&gt; duplicate tags found
</panel>

**58 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** %%(commented on own PR)%%

Interesting question. Warren and I discussed this previously. The decision is made on 2 reasons:
1. `model::hasApplication` traces to `Application::equals`, which is a strict equality check involving `ApplicationStatus` too. This may not be desirable as the guard condition serves to filter for preexisting applications of matching person and job regardless of the unknown application status within.
2. It is foreseeable that at the `UniqueApplicationList::contains` level, the method invocation switches from `Application::equals` to `Application::isSameApplication`. While this has the value-add of being more natural, the current implementation of `getApplicationsByPersonAndJob` has an alternative value-add of being more performant (it is adaptive vs stream filters and can execute in a smaller big-O time complexity of O(|smallList|) vs O(|bigList|*|smallList|) linearly).
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103T-T08-4/tp/pull/124#discussion_r2022539103" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**59 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** %%(commented on own PR)%%
</div>

Referring to Copilot's review, the check for `applicationToAdd` has been refactored to account for `NullPointerException`. Additionally, the check here serves as defensive programming and a form of consistency for `Object::equals` overrides to be strictest possible. Besides, the `applicationToAdd` is in-fact included as a parameter (elevated status from a local variable) so that its `toString` implemented by Warren can be used in static `MESSAGE_SUCCESS` as a better UI rendering to end-user.
</panel>

The intended behaviour should be that duplicate indexes are treated as if it were specified once only

I think the logic here can and should be heavily simplified. Should not use hash sets, as that uses equals and hashcode to do comparisons, but this is not what we want - we want to compare by the weaker notion of isSameJob/isSamePerson. Also, applications by definition are unique, so whats the point of throwing them into a hashSet?

Suggest to just call getApplicationsByPerson, run a for loop, and extract out those applications that satisfy isSameJob as the querying job.
</panel>

Just checking was there a specific reason for changing the implementation of `separateNewFromExisting()`? 

From my understanding, the original implementation relied on `Set.contains()`, which in turn uses the overridden `Tag.equals()` method. For reference, here‚Äôs the [Set.contains() documentation](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/util/Set.html#contains(java.lang.Object)). Since `Tag.equals()` was implemented to be case-insensitive, `Set.contains()` should correctly identify duplicates regardless of case, making it suitable for commands like `remove-tags`.

The current stream implementation also leverages `Tag.equals()` within `.filter()`, but instead of returning a boolean, it returns a `Tag` object, which is then checked for non-nullity to determine its existence, which achieves the same core logic as the previous implementation?

Could you clarify if there‚Äôs a functional or design reason for this change? Do correct me if i misunderstood, thanks!

**44 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** %%(commented on own PR)%%
</div>

From my understanding, a HashSet in Java uses a HashMap internally, and it determines if two objects are ‚Äúequal‚Äù (i.e., duplicates) based on:
  1. `hashCode()`: First, it checks whether the hash codes of the two objects are equal.
  2. `equals()`: If the hash codes match, it then uses the equals() method to check for actual object equality.

So I thought that when I override `equals()` implementation to use `equalsIgnoreCase`, I must also override `hashCode()` accordingly to maintain consistency. [According to the general contract of `hashCode()` and `equals()` is:
If a.equals(b) returns true, then a.hashCode() == b.hashCode() must also return true.](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/util/Set.html#hashCode())

So, using `equalsIgnoreCase` in `equals() `means I have to also generate the hash code in a case-insensitive manner, hence I converted it to lower-case.
</panel>

> I have tested the code and it is mostly functional, but I have some doubts.
> 
> 1. Currently, issuing a save  command deletes the existing savefile and creates a new file with the specified filename. Effectively, this merely renames the savefile and prevents the user from making a backup([As a cautious user, I want both automatic and manual saving of my contacts list so that I always have a backup and not lose my data.¬†#20](https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103-F10-1/tp/issues/20)) via the save command.
> 2. We've lost AB3's autosave functionality(needed for story [As a cautious user, I want both automatic and manual saving of my contacts list so that I always have a backup and not lose my data.¬†#20](https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103-F10-1/tp/issues/20)). I'm not sure if this regression is intentional?
> 3. An error is thrown if more than 1 json file is present in the data directory - this causes the application to try and default to arthive.json as the save file. This naturally occurs when a save command is issued with a filename parameter. This prevents users from keeping backup json files in the same directory.
> 
> This is what I think we should do instead:
> 
> 1. Retain autosave functionality from AB3
> 2. When the user issues a save command with no filename parameter, save to the current savefile (specified in preferences.json).
> 3. When the user issues a save command with a filename parameter, the addressbook is saved to the user-specified file path. This new file is created with the intention of serving as a backup file. ArtHive will not modify preferences.json, and further operations will be performed on the path loaded on application start. This behaviour would mirror the behaviour of Vim's :w command.
> 
> Requesting your thoughts @0x4F776C @kennethsoh @CJ-783 @broccoli-hater.
> 
> As these aren't absolutely trivial changes and I don't want to be a backseat driver, I have made these changes on a copy of @0x4F776C 's enhance-save-feature branch, and can issue a PR to @0x4F776C 's branch.

I agree with points 1 and 2, but not point 3.

From my understanding of your idea of "save", you are intending to do a snapshot of the current json file, by creating a new file, then keeping it in the data folder forever until manually removed. This is not the same as what we specified in the feature specification, or it could be that the feature spec is not sufficiently specific. 

In any case, I think this idea of a snapshot or "archive" is not the same as the "(manual) save" as stated in ([As a cautious user, I want both automatic and manual saving of my contacts list so that I always have a backup and not lose my data.¬†#20](https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103-F10-1/tp/issues/20)). We might have a totally separate "snapshot" or "archive" feature that can be implemented in the future.

</panel>

parse is invoked on LogicManager -&gt; parseConfirmation called on addressBookParser -&gt; executeConfirmed -&gt; commandTracker.getInstance() -&gt; CT.push() -&gt; parseCommand(...) -&gt; execute -&gt; commandResult

So there are a lot more moving parts that are currently not covered in this diagram.

My suggestion is to proceed with the following steps (in order):
1. Revert to the most recent commit where the codebase passes all (unmodified) test cases. This ensures we start from a stable foundation.
2. Rename the classes using the IDE‚Äôs(IntelliJ) refactoring tools, following the naming conventions we've agreed upon. This step will help us maintain a functioning codebase moving forward. 
3. Once the class renaming is completed, we can collaboratively work on the add and delete commands. We can split the work by components, and each of us can handle the necessary modifications and relevant tests.

I believe it is **critical** to have a working code base at the beginning of step 3. 

Additionally, for Step 2, we should avoid manually adding or renaming classes, as it‚Äôs easy to overlook errors. Using the IDE‚Äôs refactoring tools is essential to ensure accuracy and consistency.

</div>

WTD if you accidentally coded, committed and pushed on `master` in your own fork

1. Create a new branch, name it whatever
2. Do a small change, commit on **this specific branch**
3. Type these commands into CLI:

`git checkout master` (brings you back to master)

`git reset --hard HEAD~1` (reverts by `1` commit, please adjust based on how many commits to rollback on)

`git push --force origin master` (pushes these reverted changes to master, --force required as it's a backward change)

Now your `master` branch should be back to its original state, and the new branch contains all your changes! 

</panel>

</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103T-T08-3/tp/pull/231#discussion_r2016217110" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**11 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on others PR)
</div>

Yo, I get what you're saying about LSP. Right now, isSamePerson works differently for Person and Customer. For Person, it's just comparing names, but for Customer, it's using phone numbers. So, if we treat a Customer as a Person, the results might not be what we expect.

Making Person abstract could help since it stops isSamePerson from having a default behavior and having the isSamePerson method in Person as an abstract method makes sense since it forces all subclasses to define their own logic.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103T-T08-3/tp/pull/231#discussion_r2016255805" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**12 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** (commented on others PR)
</div>

I see your concern. I think the main issue might be that getFilteredList(Class&lt;T> type) uses unchecked casting. Since Person is now abstract and we have different subclasses like Staff and Customer, the list will contain mixed types.

What if a part of the code expects only Staff but accidentally gets a Customer? That could cause unexpected errors at runtime. Maybe we should check if there's a safer way to filter without risking type issues. Do you think we should add tests to catch potential errors early?
</panel>

- New order feature by @mogmyij in #83 
### Now you can track your orders with PowerBake with the new Order feature! üéä 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5b304311-2f2e-48f8-97ca-7c577186511d)


  - Each order tracks:
    - Client who made the order
    - Date and Time of when the order was made
    - Name and quantity of each pastry ordered
    - Total amount of the order
    - Status of the order


- New View order command by @cyhni in #107 
### Viewing orders has never been easier!

**Before**

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c6996693-8937-41ea-902b-eeac56c59d5a)

**After**

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b7609576-7cd7-4fa5-af96-28486101eb6e)

View all of your orders and their statuses in one glance and select specific orders to view in greater detail!
simply use the 'view order [index]' command

Command example
'view order'
'view order 3'

- New Add order command @Mil-leon in #104 
### Adding new orders is a breeze üèÅ 
**Command structure:** 'add order CLIENT_INDEX -pn [PASTRY_NAME] -q [QUANTITY]

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/183f5be7-bccf-4aca-aedc-de73cb453169)

**After**

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c8fca448-76db-43b4-b9a3-c270ab7f72f8)
You can add multiple entries of pastries when creating an order simply use the "-pn" command flag followed by "-q" again to specify the pastry name and quantity!

- New Delete order command by @Emmanuel2001 in #106 
### Made a mistake? No worries!
**Command Structure:** 'delete order ORDER_INDEX'

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/86f5b946-ded9-4ec5-a3d1-6bd0ea1d9772)

**After**

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/515a34b0-37b4-4521-ad20-03c676628e65)

It is easy to delete any wrong orders simply supply the index!

- New UI for viewing orders by @mihirniyogi in #92 
### Information at your fingertips! View all critical information at a glance!

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/36606d58-d6b3-48ce-b308-4e80e5d7e0b7)

**Legend:**
  1. Displays the current tab you are viewing
  2. Quick overview of all your current orders including all basic information
  3. Status of the Order to ensure you never miss an order
  4. detailed view of the order invoked by using the 'view order [ORDER_INDEX]' command

- New edit command for pastries by @Emmanuel2001 in #84 
### Made a mistake? Don't worry edit command got your back!

**Command Structure:** 'edit pastry PASTRY_INDEX -n [NEW_NAME] -pr [NEW_PRICE]'

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ef6d81cf-d221-4391-a19c-5ce4527f2473)

**After**

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f7b25774-7560-43b9-882b-7f80f4d1f1c8)

Using exceptions as flow control should be avoided (though I used, can't figure out any other way). Instead, you can use regex for this. 
The regex used is: `\\b(1[0-9]``{``2``}``|[2-9][0-9]``{``2,``}``)\\b`. This pattern matches numbers between 100 - 199 (1 followed by two digits) or 200 and above (2-9 followed by at least two digits).

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103-F10-1/tp/pull/123#issuecomment-2726062139" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**19 :octicon-comment:** %%(other comment)%%
</div>

Hi, I've taken a look at your latest commit. The app is working, but I'm now frankly confused as to what form our save feature is/should be taking.

As of this latest commit, the save command has the following behaviour when given a filename parameter NEW_FILENAME:

1. Creates a new save file in the data directory called NEW_FILENAME.json and saves NEW_FILENAME to preferences.json
2. Subsequent changes within the same session continue being saved to original save file (?)
3. Upon restarting of the application, NEW_FILENAME is loaded and changes made within this new session are saved to NEW_FILENAME

Side note: if a save command is issued in a session, and the application is restarted, save commands in the new session seem to create additional files without purging older save files. This could clutter the directory. 

Following the discussion in #100 : I was under the impression that when a save command is issued with a filename parameter it should behave as follows,
 
1. It should effectively just change the save file's path
2. The save command should not function as an archive-type command
3. Only one file should exist in the data directory to prevent clutter

That is, if the user starts the application with a save file named arthive.json, and issues a save command with filename parameter (e.g. save NEW_FILENAME), the command should delete arthive.json, save the current contents to NEW_FILENAME.json, and save all future changes in the current session to NEW_FILENAME.json. Additionally, user preferences are updated to reflect the use of NEW_FILENAME.json in subsequent sessions. 

@0x4F776C @kennethsoh @CJ-783 @broccoli-hater requesting your input as I fear that I might be misunderstanding a critical feature in our application. A discussion about this might help us ensure the user guide is clear and unambiguous.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103-F10-1/tp/pull/100#issuecomment-2708345492" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**26 :octicon-comment:** %%(other comment)%%
</div>

> I have tested the code and it is mostly functional, but I have some doubts.
> 
>     1. Currently, issuing a save  command deletes the existing savefile and creates a new file with the specified filename. Effectively, this merely renames the savefile and prevents the user from making a backup([As a cautious user, I want both automatic and manual saving of my contacts list so that I always have a backup and not lose my data. #20](https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103-F10-1/tp/issues/20)) via the save command.
> 
>     2. We've lost AB3's autosave functionality(needed for story [As a cautious user, I want both automatic and manual saving of my contacts list so that I always have a backup and not lose my data. #20](https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103-F10-1/tp/issues/20)). I'm not sure if this regression is intentional?
> 
>     3. An error is thrown if more than 1 json file is present in the data directory - this causes the application to try and default to arthive.json as the save file. This naturally occurs when a save command is issued with a filename parameter. This prevents users from keeping backup json files in the same directory.
> 
> 
> This is what I think we should do instead:
> 
>     1. Retain autosave functionality from AB3
> 
>     2. When the user issues a save command with no filename parameter, save to the current savefile (specified in preferences.json).
> 
>     3. When the user issues a save command with a filename parameter, the addressbook is saved to the user-specified file path. This new file is created with the intention of serving as a backup file. ArtHive will not modify preferences.json, and further operations will be performed on the path loaded on application start. This behaviour would mirror the behaviour of Vim's :w command.
> 
> 
> Requesting your thoughts @0x4F776C @kennethsoh @CJ-783 @broccoli-hater.
> 
> As these aren't absolutely trivial changes and I don't want to be a backseat driver, I have made these changes on a copy of @0x4F776C 's enhance-save-feature branch, and can issue a PR to @0x4F776C 's branch.


For point 3 if I understand you correctly, you are suggesting that if a user were to run the save command with filename parameter, it would create a backup file which will not be modified

Instead of modifying the current "save" command to handle both saving and backing up, perhaps it would be better if we add this feature in a separate functionality in the future rather than in the MVP version.

Although I understand the intent of creating this backup functionality automatically when we run the save command, I feel like the save command should retain its core functionality, which is to just save it into the arthive.json. 

Perhaps in the future, we can introduce a new feature specifically for creating backup of the file with a separate command, which would allow the user to save a copy of their data without affecting the active save file.
</panel>

**17 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** %%(commented on own PR)%%
</div>

This allows us to compare Customers/Staff
- given x = Person with name "X"
- given y = Person with name "Y"
- given cx = Customer with name "X", cid "C1"
- given cy = Customer with name "Y", cid "C2"

x.isSamePerson(y) is false
x.isSamePerson(x) is true
cx.isSamePerson(cy) is false
cx.isSamePerson(cx) is true
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103T-T08-3/tp/pull/231#discussion_r2016072290" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**18 :octicon-git-pull-request::octicon-comment:** %%(commented on own PR)%%
</div>

However, I am afraid of violation of LSP.
- given x = Person with name "X"
- given y = Person with name "Y"
- x.isSamePerson(y) is false

however, if x and y are Customers,
- x.isSamePerson(y) could be true.

I think this issue can mitigated if we define Person as an abstract class (Person::isSamePerson has no behaviour to inherit).
</panel>

# Unprescribe Command Bug Report
## Bug 1: `unprescribe` Command provides incorrect error message when invalid index provided

**Main Issue:**
`unprescribe` Command provides incorrect error message when certain invalid indexes are provided

**Description:**
When executing the `unprescribe` command with certain invalid indexes (like `-1`, `0` and `-1000`), the error message provided is `incorrect command format!` instead of `The patient index provided is invalid`.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Launch the application
2. Ensure there is at least 1 patient in the list (Alex Yeoh at index 1)
3. Execute the command: `unprescribe -1 m/paracetamol`
4. Observe the output message: "Invalid command format! 
unprescribe: removes a medication from the patient specified by the index number used in the last patient listing. Parameters: INDEX (must be a positive integer) m/[medicine name] OR m/all
Example 1: unprescribe 1 m/Paracetamol"

**Expected Behavior:**
The system should reject the command and display an error message indicating an invalid index: `The patient index provided is invalid`

**Actual Behavior:**
The system rejects the command, but displays an `incorrect command format!` error

**Documentation Reference:**
According to the command documentation:
Removes specific or all medication from an existing patient in the patient contact book.

Format: `unprescribe INDEX m/MEDICINE_NAME` or `unprescribe INDEX m/all`

* Removes medication from the patient at the specified `INDEX`. The index refers to the index 
  number shown in the displayed patient list. The index **must be a positive integer** 1, 2, 3, ‚Ä¶‚Äã
* `unprescribe INDEX m/all` removes all medication from the list 

**Severity:**
Low - The command executes correctly, but the error message could confuse the user, since the command format is technically correct.

**Suggested Fix:**
Modify the command parser to validate that an index of 0 and below (negative) should return the invalid index error message (`The patient index provided is invalid`).

**Screenshot:**
<img width="856" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0ba7149b-fb4d-48b1-a52b-309e83562fe3" />



## Bug 2: `unprescribe` command allows multiple medicines to be specified but only removes first medicine specified

**Main Issue:**
`unprescribe` command allows multiple medicines to be specified but only removes the last medicine specified

**Description:**
When executing the `unprescribe` command, the user can specify multiple medicines to be removed but only the last medicine specified gets removed.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Launch the application
2. Ensure there is at least 1 patient in the list (Alex Yeoh at index 1), and this patient has at least two medicines (e.g. Insulin and Paracetamol)
3. Execute the command: `unprescribe 1 m/Insulin m/Paracetamol`
4. Observe that the system reports `Removed medication Paracetamol from patient: Alex Yeoh`

**Expected Behavior:**
The system should either:
- Inform the user that only 1 medicine can be specified at a time
OR
- Remove all specified medicines (if all are valid) from the specified patient

**Actual Behavior:**
The system displays a success message `Removed medication Paracetamol from patient: Alex Yeoh` and only removes the last specified medication (Paracetamol in this case).

**Severity:**
Medium - This issue provides misleading feedback to users but doesn't cause data loss or prevent functionality.

**Suggested Fix:**
Modify the `unprescribe` command implementation to:
1. Remove all specified medicines from the specified patient, and display the appropriate success message accordingly IF everything is correct (valid medicine names, valid index, patient has all of the medicines specified... etc)

**Screenshot:**
<img width="856" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/566f7ee9-9621-4e1f-9afd-49c4a9785836" />


</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103T-W09-2/tp/issues/73#issuecomment-2739440700" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**24 :octicon-comment:** %%(other comment)%%
</div>

Issue: Improve EditCommand to Support Incremental Tag Mutations

Summary

Currently, the EditCommand tests and application logic revealed inconsistencies in how tags (also referred to as ‚Äúrequests‚Äù) are mutated when editing a guest. Specifically, previous test cases assumed full tag overwriting behavior. However, the intended functionality is to allow users to incrementally add or remove tags without having to reset or overwrite the entire tag set.

‚∏ª

Problem Statement
	1.	Inconsistent test assumptions:
	‚Ä¢	Some tests were expecting edited guests to have their tags completely replaced, even when only one new tag was added.
	2.	Lack of incremental tag mutation:
	‚Ä¢	The CLI currently supports +req/ and -req/ syntax to add or remove individual tags.
	‚Ä¢	However, older tests and parts of the logic assume tags are wholesale replaced on edit, which is not in line with this incremental approach.

‚∏ª

Impact
	‚Ä¢	Developers and users face confusion when editing guests as tags may not persist as expected.
	‚Ä¢	Test cases fail due to mismatches between the old assumption (replace all tags) and the correct behavior (mutate tags incrementally).
	‚Ä¢	It makes it difficult to extend tag-editing capabilities (e.g., batch add/remove) since the current implementation does not clearly separate ‚Äúoverwrite‚Äù vs. ‚Äúmutate‚Äù operations.

‚∏ª

Proposed Solution
	‚Ä¢	Ensure that EditCommand appends or removes tags incrementally while preserving existing tags unless explicitly cleared.
	‚Ä¢	Update all relevant tests (e.g., EditCommandTest.java) to match this behavior.
	‚Ä¢	Review CLI parser (EditCommandParser) to enforce clear handling for:
	‚Ä¢	+req/ (add one or more tags)
	‚Ä¢	-req/ (remove one or more tags)
	‚Ä¢	t/ (optional: fully reset tags, if needed, in a future enhancement)
	‚Ä¢	Improve documentation for developers and users on how tag mutations work.
</panel>

This bug was reviewed in 1.5 and determined no longer relevant. 

In response to the following:
```
If this is a feature, it implicitly enforces that every room has a unique guest. However, it does not enforce all guest entries to be unique, allowing for duplicate guest entries. Note: technically the original AB3 enforces unique guest by enforcing unique names, however our guest book stops enforcing this if guest ID is used instead.
```

We now enforce guest uniqueness by email, thus we ensure each guest can only book one room, and each room has at least one guest.

# Bug Report for Untag Command

## Bug 1: Errors in User Guide Documentation
**Issues Found:**
- Untag command is given as `tag` in the description
- `At least one of the optional fields must be provided.` Perhaps you could elaborate more on this sentence on what is meant by optional fields
- `Existing values will be updated to the input values` Perhaps you could give an example for this.
- `When editing tags, the existing tags of the patient will be removed i.e. adding of tags is not cumulative.` - Perhaps, you could clarify this or move this point to the edit section

### Screenshot from user guide:

<img width="817" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b38a032d-1f4b-4104-a028-e253f9385581" />

---


## Bug 2: Incorrect Error Handling when no Tag Parameters Provided

**Description:** 
`untag 2` command input reports success even when no tag parameters are provided

When executing the untag command without specifying any tag parameters (e.g., untag 2), CareConnect **incorrectly** reports success :`Tags successfully removed from Bernice Yu`, even though no tags were removed. 

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Launch the application
2. Ensure there are at least 2 patients in the list
3. Execute the command: untag 2 (without any tag parameters)
4. Observe the output message

**Expected Behaviour:**
The system should reject the command and display an error message indicating that at least one tag parameter must be provided, such as "Invalid command format! Please provide at least one tag to remove."

**Actual Behavior:**
The system accepts the command and displays: "Tags successfully removed from Bernice Yu" even though no tags were specified for removal.

**Documentation Reference:**
According to the command documentation: "At least one of the optional fields must be provided."
The correct format is `untag INDEX [t/TAG]...` where at least one tag must be specified.
Only `t/` without any tags is a valid special case to remove all tags.

**Severity:**
Medium - The system fails to provide appropriate feedback for an invalid command, which could confuse users about whether their command was processed.

**Suggested Fix:**
Modify the command parser to validate that either:
- At least one tag parameter is provided (e.g., untag 2 t/diabetes), or
- The special case syntax for removing all tags is used (e.g., untag 2 t/)

If neither condition is met, the system should display an appropriate error message.

**Screenshot:**
<img width="737" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f3d0fe19-69be-416f-9fbf-6316204ff231" />

---
## Bug 3: `untag 2 t/` Command (Remove All Tags) Not Functional 
**Description:**
When executing the command `untag 2 t/`, which according to the documentation should remove all tags from the patient at index 2, nothing happens. The system doesn't produce any visible change, error message, or confirmation, despite this being explicitly documented as a valid command to "remove all the patient's tags."

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Launch the application
2. Ensure there are at least 2 patients in the list and the patient at index 2 has at least one tag
3. Execute the command: `untag 2 t/`
4. Observe that no response is given by the system and the tags remain unchanged

**Expected Behavior:**
According to the documentation: "You can remove all the patient's tags by typing `t/` without specifying any tags after it." The system should:
- Remove all tags from the patient at index 2
- Provide confirmation of the action with a success message

**Actual Behavior:**
The command appears to be ignored. No tags are removed from the patient, and the system doesn't provide any error message, warning, or confirmation of any action.

**Documentation Reference:**
The documentation explicitly states:
- "You can remove all the patient's tags by typing `t/` without specifying any tags after it."
- This is presented as a special case for the `untag` command that should be valid.

**Severity:**
High - A documented feature is completely non-functional, which could significantly impact users who need to remove all tags from a patient.

**Suggested Fix:**
Implement the special case handling for the `untag INDEX t/` command to properly remove all tags from the specified patient, as documented in the user guide.

**Screenshot:**
<img width="736" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/eebfc449-78de-43a8-93f0-4cce00952315" />

---
## Bug 4: `untag` Command returns Success for Removing Non-existent Tags
**Description:**
The `untag` command incorrectly displays a success message when attempting to remove tags that don't exist on a patient. This gives users false feedback that something has changed when in fact no changes were made to the patient's tags.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Launch the application
2. Identify a patient (e.g., Bernice Yu at index 2) who does not have a specific tag (e.g., "boss")
3. Execute the command: `untag 2 t/boss`
4. Observe that the system reports "Tags [boss] successfully removed from Bernice Yu" despite no actual changes being made

**Expected Behavior:**
The system should either:
- Inform the user that the specified tag(s) don't exist on the patient
- Only report success if actual changes were made to the patient's tags

**Actual Behavior:**
The system displays a success message "Tags [boss] successfully removed from Bernice Yu" even when attempting to remove tags that don't exist on the patient.

**Severity:**
Medium - This issue provides misleading feedback to users but doesn't cause data loss or prevent functionality.

**Suggested Fix:**
Modify the `untag` command implementation to:
1. Check if the specified tags exist on the patient before attempting removal
2. Only display success messages when actual changes are made
3. Provide appropriate feedback when attempting to remove non-existent tags, such as "Tag [boss] not found on Bernice Yu"

**Screenshot:**

<img width="723" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/df7122cd-65e5-4d95-be87-806516651f9c" />
---

# Bug Report: `help` Command Ignores Extra Parameters

**Main Issue:**
`help` command processes invalid input with extra parameters

**Description:**
The `help` command incorrectly accepts and processes commands with additional parameters (e.g., `help me`). According to the documentation, the help command should only be used in the format `help` without any additional parameters.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Launch the application
2. Execute the command: `help me` (with an additional parameter)
3. Observe that the system still shows the help message as if the command was valid

**Expected Behaviour:**
The system should reject the command and display an error message indicating that the help command doesn't accept additional parameters, such as "Invalid command format! The help command doesn't take any parameters."

**Actual Behavior:**
The system accepts the command `help me` and displays the help message as if a correct `help` command was entered.

**Documentation Reference:**
According to the command documentation:
* The correct format is simply `help` with no additional parameters
* The documentation doesn't indicate that the command should accept additional text

**Severity:**
Low - The command still achieves its primary function of showing help information, but it accepts invalid syntax which could confuse users about proper command format requirements.

**Suggested Fix:**
Modify the command parser to strictly validate the help command format and reject any help commands with additional parameters. The system should display an appropriate error message when extra parameters are provided and also provide guidance to the user on the correct `help` command format.

**Additional Notes:**
While this bug doesn't prevent users from accessing help information, it creates inconsistency in how command validation is handled throughout the application. Other commands likely enforce their parameter requirements strictly, so the help command should maintain the same level of validation.

**Screenshot:**
<img width="741" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c065bf91-a0d2-46e9-b3b0-2063d3469dae" />

# Bug Report for Edit Command

## Bug 1: Insufficient Phone Number Validation in `edit` Command
**Main Issue:**
`edit` command accepts invalid phone numbers for Singapore context

**Description:**
The `edit` command incorrectly accepts phone numbers that don't conform to Singapore's standard 8-digit format. Currently, the application only validates that phone numbers are at least 3 digits, which allows users to input invalid phone numbers that wouldn't be usable in a Singapore healthcare context.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Launch the application
2. Execute a command like: `edit 1 p/123456` (a 6-digit number)
3. Observe that the system accepts this invalid phone number format
4. Similarly, the system also accepts longer numbers like `p/12345678901`

**Expected Behavior:**
For a Singapore-based patient management system, the phone number validation should:
- Only accept 8-digit phone numbers (Singapore's standard format)
- Possibly only accept numbers starting with valid Singapore prefixes (8 or 9 for mobile, 6 for landline)
- Reject numbers that don't conform to these standards with a clear error message

**Actual Behavior:**
The system accepts any phone number that is at least 3 digits, regardless of whether it conforms to Singapore's phone number format. This allows invalid data to be stored in the system.

**Documentation Reference:**
While the documentation doesn't explicitly state the validation requirements for phone numbers, a healthcare application for Singapore users should enforce locally valid phone number formats.

**Severity:**
Medium - This issue allows invalid data to be stored in the system, which could lead to communication problems when attempting to contact patients.

**Suggested Fix:**
Modify the phone number validation to:
1. Strictly enforce 8-digit phone numbers
2. Optionally validate that mobile numbers start with 8 or 9, and landlines with 6
3. Provide clear error messages that explain the required format
4. Provide documentation on phone number requirements in user guide 

**Additional Notes:**
Proper validation is particularly important in healthcare applications where reaching patients reliably is crucial. Storing invalid phone numbers could lead to missed appointments or inability to contact patients in emergencies.

**Screenshot:**
<img width="721" alt="Image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6fdb0b93-5283-4d6b-8785-6d6057fd44a0" />

---

## Bug 2: Incomplete Documentation for Tag Editing Behavior

**Main Issue:**
User guide lacks clear explanation of tag editing behavior with `edit` command

**Description:**
The user guide's documentation for the `edit` command lacks important information about how tag editing works. While it mentions that "adding of tags is not cumulative," it fails to explicitly document two critical behaviors:
1. Using `edit INDEX t/` (with empty tag value) deletes all tags
2. Using `edit INDEX t/tag1 t/tag2 t/tag3` completely replaces existing tags with the new set

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Review the user guide documentation for the `edit` command
2. Note that while it mentions tags are "not cumulative," it doesn't provide explicit examples of these important tag editing behaviors

**Expected Behavior:**
The documentation should clearly explain all aspects of tag editing, including:
- Explicit statement that `edit INDEX t/` removes all tags
- Clear examples showing how multiple tags replace existing tags
- Explanation that each tag editing operation completely overwrites previous tags

**Actual Behavior:**
The documentation only vaguely states that "adding of tags is not cumulative" without providing clear examples or explanations of the complete tag editing functionality.

**Documentation Reference:**
Current documentation states:
* "When editing tags, the existing tags of the patient will be removed i.e. adding of tags is not cumulative."
* It provides an example: `edit 2 n/Betsy Crower t/` but doesn't explicitly state this removes all tags.

**Severity:**
Medium - Missing documentation could lead to user confusion and unintentional data loss when editing tags.

**Suggested Fix:**
Update the documentation to clearly explain all tag editing behaviors:
1. Add an explicit statement: "Using `edit INDEX t/` removes all tags from the patient."
2. Add explanation: "When using multiple tags like `edit INDEX t/tag1 t/tag2`, all existing tags are replaced with the new set."
3. Include more comprehensive examples showing different tag editing scenarios.

**Additional Notes:**
Clear documentation is especially important for features that can result in data removal. Users need to fully understand how tag editing works to avoid accidentally removing important patient information.

participant "<<static>>\nParserUtil" as ParserUtil LOGIC_COLOR

EditTripParser -&gt; ParserUtil : parseItinerary()

> I have tested the code and it is mostly functional, but I have some doubts.
> 
> 1. Currently, issuing a save  command deletes the existing savefile and creates a new file with the specified filename. Effectively, this merely renames the savefile and prevents the user from making a backup([As a cautious user, I want both automatic and manual saving of my contacts list so that I always have a backup and not lose my data.¬†#20](https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103-F10-1/tp/issues/20)) via the save command.
> 2. We've lost AB3's autosave functionality(needed for story [As a cautious user, I want both automatic and manual saving of my contacts list so that I always have a backup and not lose my data.¬†#20](https://github.com/AY2425S2-CS2103-F10-1/tp/issues/20)). I'm not sure if this regression is intentional?
> 3. An error is thrown if more than 1 json file is present in the data directory - this causes the application to try and default to arthive.json as the save file. This naturally occurs when a save command is issued with a filename parameter. This prevents users from keeping backup json files in the same directory.
> 
> This is what I think we should do instead:
> 
> 1. Retain autosave functionality from AB3
> 2. When the user issues a save command with no filename parameter, save to the current savefile (specified in preferences.json).
> 3. When the user issues a save command with a filename parameter, the addressbook is saved to the user-specified file path. This new file is created with the intention of serving as a backup file. ArtHive will not modify preferences.json, and further operations will be performed on the path loaded on application start. This behaviour would mirror the behaviour of Vim's :w command.
> 
> Requesting your thoughts @0x4F776C @kennethsoh @CJ-783 @broccoli-hater.
> 
> As these aren't absolutely trivial changes and I don't want to be a backseat driver, I have made these changes on a copy of @0x4F776C 's enhance-save-feature branch, and can issue a PR to @0x4F776C 's branch.

I see! So we are integrating an **archive** feature into the **save**  feature instead of sticking with plain file saving? I can make that work easily :D However, how are we going to deal with the number of stagnant files?
</panel>

### Void Issue Explanation

The issue is void because the `assign` command **should allow assigning an existing duty date** to multiple personnel, even if one or more already have it.

#### Example Scenario

- Personnel 1 already has a duty on `2025-05-30`.
- User enters the following command:
- assign 1 2 3 d/2025-05-30


#### Expected Behavior

- The command should **execute successfully**.
- It should assign the duty on `2025-05-30` to Personnel 1, 2, and 3.
- No error should be thrown, even if some already have the duty date assigned.

#### Justification

- Re-assigning an existing duty should be **idempotent** and **non-blocking**.
- This ensures a smoother user experience when batch-assigning duties.

</panel>

Yes, the original method works well for case-insensitivity :) The change was made to address the bug pointed out by @delonlee01 where the message would show the version of the tag that the user input (e.g. FriEnDs) as "already in the person's list" instead of the version that is actually in the list (if the person's existing tag is "Friends")

# Feature: Show the commissions received from each downline over their lifetime in a list

## Purpose
Enables users to quickly view the total commissions earned from each downline recorded in the AddressBook. This helps identify the most valuable downlines at a glance, aiding in financial tracking or reporting. Only contacts labelled downlines can have commissions.

---

## Command Format

lc [optional flags]
- **Short command:** `lc`
- **Optional Sorting Flag:**  
  - `/sort <direction>` where `<direction>` is either `asc` or `desc`  
  - Example usage: `lc /sort asc` or `lc /sort desc`

If no sorting flag is provided, the application may display the results in a default order (e.g., alphabetical by name, or by most recently updated).

---

## Example Commands

1. **Basic (no sorting)**  
lc
- Displays the list of each downline and their lifetime commissions in the default order.

2. **Sorted (ascending)**  
lc /sort asc
- Displays the list sorted by total commissions in ascending order (lowest commission first).

3. **Sorted (descending)**  
lc /sort desc
- Displays the list sorted by total commissions in descending order (highest commission first).

---

## Parameters & Validation Rules

### **No Mandatory Parameters**
- By default, `lc` requires no parameters.

### **Optional Sorting Parameter**
- **Syntax:** `/sort <direction>`
- **Acceptable Values:**  
- `"asc"` or `"desc"` (case-insensitive, e.g., `ASC` or `Asc` is valid).
- **Invalid if:**  
- Any other value is provided (e.g., `/sort random`).
- **Error Message (on invalid sort direction):**  
"Invalid sort direction. Use '/sort asc' or '/sort desc'."
---

## Outputs

### On Success
- **Command:** `lc [optional sorting flag]`
- **Behavior:**  
1. **Lists each downline** in the AddressBook.  
2. **Shows their lifetime commissions** (the total amount received from each contact).  
3. **Applies sorting** if `/sort asc` or `/sort desc` is specified.

- **Example Successful Output:**
Here is the total commission for each downline:
1. John Doe - $12,000
2. Jane Smith - $9,250
3. Mike Johnson - $2,500

### On Failure
1. **No Downline Found**
"No Downline in the address book."
2. **Invalid Sorting Flag**
"Invalid sort direction. Use '/sort asc' or '/sort desc'."
---

## Possible Errors & Edge Cases
1. **No Commission Records**
- **Description:** Contacts exist, but none have a commission value.
- **Response:** Display `$0.00` or `N/A` for each contact instead of showing an error.

2. **Unrecognized Command Input**
- **Example:** `lc somethingExtra`
- **Response:**  
  ```
  "Unrecognized parameter 'somethingExtra'. Type 'help lc' for usage."
  ```

---
